subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
{{zh-ref|Norman and Mei (1976)}} propose that this was a substrate loan; cf. {{cog|mkh-vie-pro|*Å‹aË||[[ivory]]}} ({{cog|vi|ngÃ }}), {{cog|tai-pro|*Å‹aËá´¬||[[tusk]]; [[ivory]]}} ({{cog|th|à¸‡à¸²}}). {{zh-ref|Pulleyblank (1983)}} disagrees with their hypothesis and considers Old Chinese to be the donor of this [[Wanderwort]] instead.

STEDT provisionally sets up {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*s-Å‹ja||tusk; tooth}}, comparing it to {{cog|lus|ngho||tusk; fang}}, {{cog|mni|tr=ya|t=tooth}}, {{cog|mro|tr=hngou|t=tooth}}, {{cog|blk|tr=tÉ™ÌÊ” '''Å‹Ã '''|t=tooth}}.

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: Although this term is no longer used in isolation, it does persist in certain compounds.

subSections.title: Derived terms
Etymology 2
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|ãã°}}
Compound of {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=ãã°}} elements {{compound|ja|sort=ãã°|ç‰™|tr1=ki|t1=fang, tusk|æ­¯|tr2=ha|t2=tooth}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> {{rendaku2|sort=ãã°|ha|ba}}

subSections.title: Noun
Usage notes
subSections.text: This is the most common term for {{m|en|fang}} in modern Japanese.

subSections.title: Etymology 3
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|ã‹ã³}}
Cognate with, and probably the noun derivation of, verb {{m|ja|é»´ã³ã‚‹|tr=kabiru||to go moldy}}, from the root idea of something [[sprout]]ing.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> Used in the ''[[w:Kojiki|Kojiki]]''.

subSections.title: Etymology 5
Usage notes
subSections.text: The {{m|en|tooth}} meaning is much more commonly expressed using the word {{m|ja|æ­¯|tr=ha}}.

subSections.title: Etymology 6
Usage notes
subSections.text: The ''ga'' reading is only used in compounds, and is never used in isolation.
